ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CBA  –  Central Bank of Armenia 
  GDP  –  gross domestic product 
GMRA  –  Global Master Repurchase Agreement 
IMF  –  International Monetary Fund 
  MOE  –  Ministry of Economy 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  MTDS  –  Medium-Term Debt Strategy 
  PDMD  –  Public Debt Management Department 
  PPEF  –  post-program engagement framework 
  PPP  –  public–private partnership 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
GLOSSARY 
 
  Bond switch  –  Two parties agree to respectively switch ownership of two 
different bonds at an agreed price difference (i.e., for a 5-year–
10-year bond switch, party A would buy a 5-year bond from 
party B who would simultaneously be contractually bound to 
buy a 10-year bond from party A at agreed prices). Debt 
managers use switches to build-up benchmark issues and 
reduce  the  liquidity  impact  of  benchmark  bonds  nearing 
maturity. 
  Benchmark issue  –  A  bond  that  provides  a  standard  against  which  the 
performance of other bonds can be measured. Government 
bonds are used as benchmark bonds. Benchmark issues are 
typically used as the basis of yield curves. 
  Financial  –  Percentage  of  foreign  currency  loans  in  total  loans  or 
dollarization  percentage  of  foreign  currency  deposits  in  total  deposits. 
(domestic liability  Excessive financial dollarization hinders the ability of domestic 
dollarization)  policy makers to deploy policy instruments which can help 
mitigate the impacts of external shocks. 
  Global Market  –  GMRA  is  a  model  legal  agreement  designed  for  parties 
Repurchase  transacting repos and is published by the International Capital 
Agreement  Market Association (ICMA), which is the body representing the 
cross-border bond and repo markets in Europe. Adoption of 
GMRA in Armenia will enable increased operational efficiency 
of the market as a whole and harmonize market practice. Its 
standardization  will  also  allow  repo  transactions  to  be 
comparable and represented by legal interest rate indexes, a

crucial element for monetary policy and a pre-condition for the 
introduction of variable-rate instruments. 
  Hedging  –  Hedging instrument is a general term that refers to all the 
Instruments  financial instruments used by investors aiming to offset the 
potential changes in the fair value or cash flows of their hedged 
items.  Hedging  instruments  are  also  crucial  for  financial 
arbitrage, i.e. the simultaneous purchase and sale of an asset 
to profit from an imbalance in the price or to exploit price 
differences  of  identical  or  similar  financial  instruments  on 
different markets or in different forms, a crucial pre-condition 
of efficiency in financial markets. 
  IFRS 16  –  The objective of IFRS 16 is to report information that (a) 
faithfully  represents  lease  transactions  and  (b)  provides  a 
basis for users of financial statements to assess the amount, 
timing and uncertainty of cash flows arising from leases. 
  Interest rate risk  –  Interest rate risk is the danger that the value of a bond or other 
fixed-income investment will suffer as the result of a change in 
interest rates. 
  Market making  –  Market making is typically required of primary dealers to offer 
both a buy price and a sell price for the same security. 
  Medium Term  –  The Medium Term Debt Management Strategy (MTDS) is a 
Debt Strategy  plan that Government intends to implement over the medium 
term  to  achieve  a  composition  of  the  debt  portfolio  that 
captures its preferences with regard to the cost-risk trade-off. 
  Money Market  –  Market  where financial instruments  such  as  treasury  bills, 
corporate notes, and repurchase agreements are used by 
financial  institutions  to  fund  their  short-term  liquidity 
requirements  or  invest  their  short-term  cash  surpluses. 
Developing money markets helps provide banks with more 
certainty over the size of the deposit pool they can rely on to 
fund their long term loans to project their liquidity needs and 
lend or borrow cash from the markets to balance their books 
(key aspects of maturity transformation — explained in more 
detail below). 
  Money market  –  Financial  Market  Infrastructure  (FMI)  refers  to  critically 
infrastructure  important  institutions  responsible  for  providing  clearing, 
settlement  and  recording  of  monetary  and  other  financial 
transactions.  A  payment  system  is  a  set  of  instruments, 
procedures, and rules for the transfer of funds between or 
among participants. 
  Armenia Stock  –  AMX is the only stock exchange in Armenia, operating for 
Exchange “AMX”  almost 17 years. It provides the Market with a fully automated 
trading system. 
  Price discovery  –  Price discovery refers to the act of determining the proper price 
of  a  security,  commodity,  or  good  or  service  by  studying 
market supply and demand and other factors associated with 
transactions. 
  Primary Dealing  –  Primary dealers bid for government contracts competitively 
and purchase the majority of Treasury bills, bonds, and notes

at auction. Primary government securities dealers sell the 
Treasury securities that they buy from the central bank to their 
clients, creating the initial market. 
  Refinancing risk  –  Refinancing risk, in banking and finance, is the possibility that 
a borrower cannot refinance by borrowing to repay existing 
debt. Refinancing risk increases during rising interest rates, as 
the borrower may not have sufficient income to afford the 
higher interest rate on a new loan. 
  Regular  –  A  program  that  provides  a constant supply  of  benchmark 
Treasury Bill  Treasury bills issued by auction on a regular basis (weekly 
Program  and/or fortnightly) across a range of key maturities (one or 
more of 90, 180, 270, 365 days), and is generally self-funding 
as the same principal value is issued in each auction. 
  Repurchase  –  A form of short-term borrowing for dealers in government 
agreement  securities.  The  dealer  sells  the  government  securities  to 
(“repo”)  investors, usually on an overnight basis, with an agreement to 
repurchase them at a set term for a set purchase price which 
includes  interest.  For  the  party  selling  the  security  (and 
agreeing to repurchase it in the future), it is a repo; for the party 
on the other end of the transaction (buying the security and 
agreeing to sell in the future), it is a reverse repo agreement. 
       
       
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars and € refers to Euros.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based loan to Armenia for the Second Public Efficiency and Financial Markets Program. 
2.  The proposed program will help strengthen fiscal sustainability and develop financial and 
capital markets in Armenia. It builds on previous Asian Development Bank (ADB) programmatic 
assistance  to  Armenia  and  the  reform  momentum  maintained  through  its  post-program 
engagement framework. Reforms under the proposed program aim to further (i) strengthen the 
management of public debt and fiscal risks to support the authorities’ efforts towards fiscal 
consolidation; (ii) improve interbank markets liquidity by deepening the government securities 
market and improving the infrastructure for money markets; and (iii) foster the development of 
capital markets by enhancing the legal and regulatory framework for new instruments and 
investment vehicles.1 This medium-term reform agenda will also help deliver more predictable 
fiscal outcomes over time, as required by the new government program of February 2019 (Para 
10). A second Post-Program Engagement Framework (PPEF) is also proposed to assist with 
reform objectives during 2020-2021. The proposed support is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 
2030, which prioritizes developing market institutions to support private sector development and 
enhance financial stability.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
3.  Potential output growth in Armenia is partly limited by low levels of investment, which 
declined from about 40% of gross domestic product (GDP) before the global financial crisis to 
less than 18% in 2017–2018.3 A strong and sustainable rebound is unlikely unless reforms 
address the high costs of local currency finance and the constraints to the financial system’s own 
capacity to generate medium-term lending.4 Pricing benchmarks for financial contracts in local 
currency are currently nonexistent for medium-term tenors or are very steep at the short-term 
tenors available.5 Foreign currency lending remains common practice in the banking sector, 
whether the parties recognize the key risks or not. The consequence is that the economy remains 
dollarized,  vulnerable  to  external  shocks,  and,  indirectly,  also  constrained  from  a  price 
competitiveness perspective.6 Promoting financial deepening in local currency is a priority, and 
also requires key efficiency-promoting upgrades in public investment and fiscal management. 
                                                
1  Reform processes in these areas were initiated under ADB. 2017. Report and Recommendation of the President to 
the Board of Directors: Proposed Programmatic Approach and Policy-Based Loan for Subprogram 1 to Armenia for 
the Public Efficiency and Financial Markets Program. Manila. The proposed program finalizes some of these efforts. 
2  Specifically, Operational Priority 6 on strengthening governance and institutional capacity. Also see ADB. 2019. 
Country Operations Business Plan: Armenia, 2020–2022. Manila. (circulated to the ADB Board of Directors); and 
ADB. 2019. Country Partnership Strategy: Armenia, 2020–2023. Manila (circulated to the ADB Board of Directors).  
3  The pre-2009 capital inflows and credit-induced construction boom had fueled significant property investment. The 
contraction in investment as a share of GDP since then is expected to end in 2019, and pro-growth government 
policies can help revive it, especially if business environment challenges and geopolitical risks are addressed. 
4  Maturity transformation is a key function of banking. The maturity mismatch needed to facilitate long-term investment 
projects, while serving agents’ liquidity needs, is a key driver of the net interest margin in banking.  
5  At the current Central Bank of Armenia (CBA) policy rate of 5.5%, risk-free rates for highly liquid instruments with a 
5-year tenor are about 8.5% (and above 10% for a 10-year tenor). With risk premiums considered, maximum tenors 
on offer by commercial banks in local currency are now below 24 months and on average at rates of about 13%. 
6  In highly dollarized economies, short-term exchange-rate pass-through to local prices and “fear of floating” (for 
currency mismatch concerns in the private and public sectors) tend to produce a preference for nominal exchange 
rate stability in monetary policy decisions, at the expense of real effective exchange rate appreciation.

2 
4.  Core development problem. While Armenia’s financial institutions have improved over 
the years, financial markets remain nascent. 7 This limits Armenia’s private sector and banking 
development, constrains public finance and fiscal management, and threatens macroeconomic 
and financial stability.8 The proposed program builds on momentum created during the ADB 
assistance  of  2017–2018  by  addressing  key  outstanding  issues  at  the  root  of  this  core 
development problem. These issues are summarized in the three problem areas below.9  
5.  Root problem area 1: Public debt and fiscal risk management. Gaps in public debt 
and fiscal risk management still hold back fiscal credibility in Armenia and pose risks to fiscal 
consolidation.  To  ensure  fiscal  sustainability  and  sustainably  reduce  risk  premiums,  these 
functions need to continue becoming more effective and credible in meeting their core objectives. 
ADB’s programmatic assistance in 2017–2018 initiated the medium-term reform agenda to 
address these constraints (see some achievements in Para 8).10 But key upgrades still need to 
be established or completed, particularly (i) in fiscal risk management (to expand the scope of 
fiscal risks covered, the type of management exercised and its access to information, and the 
effectiveness of the function in overall terms), (ii) in public debt management (to gradually 
increase reliance on local currency market-based instruments at shorter tenors, and more reliably 
communicate strategic directions with market players), and (iii) in establishing an effective and 
credible legal and regulatory framework for private participation in infrastructure services.  
6.  Root problem area 2: Government securities and money markets. Gaps of different 
nature continue to hold back efficiency and liquidity in Armenia’s government securities and 
money markets. ADB’s previous programmatic assistance supported reforms and institutional 
development efforts to start addressing these gaps in 2017–2018 (Para 8).11 Key issues that still 
need addressing include the weak cash/liquidity management and forecasting between the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Central Bank of Armenia (CBA) and the money-markets 
volatility these difficulties create, and the need to fully implement legal and regulatory changes to 
increase  liquidity  in  secured  interbank  markets,  improve  price  discovery,  and  develop  the 
standardized safe instruments that are still missing. More formalized processes of scrutiny and 
consultation with market players about market development strategic options are still absent. 
7.  Root problem area 3: Legal frameworks and corporate transparency. Deficiencies in 
key legal frameworks for financial instruments and vehicles, and for the protection of investors, 
along with deep deficiencies in corporate transparency persist. Reform efforts implemented under 
ADB’s first program (Para 8) need to be followed up on12 with the development of the legal 
framework for new types of instruments and equity vehicles, of the insolvency framework to 
improve investors’ protection and confidence, and of the basic pillars of corporate transparency. 
                                                
7  Insurance is only about 1% of the financial system’s assets. Interbank markets are less than 10% of banks’ funding.  
8  Some 85% of Armenia’s public debt is in foreign currency. This is a fundamental source of vulnerability to shocks. 
9  A comprehensive summary of these issues is in Sector Assessment (Summary): Finance and Public Sector 
Management (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). The systemic consequences of these root 
problems are (i) high exposure to currency risks; (ii) very high and time-varying liquidity premiums for public debt 
issuance, with exchange rate premiums dominating the pricing of government securities; and (iii) high dollarization. 
10 Before ADB’s first intervention, (i) public debt management lacked effectiveness and credible strategic pillars; (ii) 
fiscal risk management lacked tools and was significantly incomplete in scope, played no role in vetting new 
initiatives, and exercised no risk management or mitigation responsibilities; and (iii) private sector provision of 
infrastructure services lacked a legal and regulatory basis and was done in nontransparent, fiscally adverse ways. 
11 Before the first ADB program, debt securities issuance practices and communication were not adequate for 
developing market benchmarks, and new practices and programs were needed to gradually reduce liquidity 
premiums in government debt securities. Lack of market-making frameworks also impeded price discovery. 
12 Before the first ADB program, there were many gaps in legal frameworks for new instruments and asset classes.

3 
B.  Policy Reform Agenda and ADB’s Value Addition 
8.  ADB’s previous programmatic assistance. The program addresses key reform areas 
that follow on from previous ADB engagement and remain pertinent to the new government in 
Armenia, as clearly specified in the government’s 2019–2023 development strategy. Under 
previous  ADB  programmatic  assistance13,  public  debt  management  was  centralized  and 
strengthened through new legal frameworks, a new PPP policy was approved to guide all the 
legal and regulatory framework work that followed, new debt issuance instruments and programs 
were introduced to improve the functioning of short-term financial markets, legal reforms were 
approved to strengthen secured interbank lending, legal reforms were achieved to promote a 
variety of securitization instruments and residential mortgage financing, regulatory reforms to 
facilitate private equity and other investment vehicles were approved, etc. A post-program 
engagement framework was key in maintaining momentum in policy dialogue, notwithstanding 
the political reform process that Armenia witnessed since late-2018. These reforms can trigger 
long-lasting changes in the institutional or policy environment. However, these take time to 
become fully embedded in Armenian institutions’ practice. Through the proposed program, ADB 
and the government continue to build on past achievements and maintain reform focus on the 
emerging issues in each reform area.  
9.  ADB’s value addition. ADB has accumulated experience in policy dialogue and in 
providing  technical  support  to  governments  in  deepening  domestic  financial  markets  while 
strengthening public management functions. Its experience in Armenia in the specific areas of the 
proposed program have also allowed it to continue developing, with the government, the general 
policy direction and specific reform efforts, even during the recent political transition in Armenia. 
This was assisted by the original technical assistance to ADB’s past programmatic assistance, 
staff consultancy resources and a regional technical assistance window in ADB.14 Technical and 
guidance notes were instrumental to contextualize proposed policy actions during the policy 
dialogue with the government. ADB’s institutional memory of the challenges and lessons in the 
first program makes its assistance increasingly more efficient in supporting the government 
through the implementation of specific multi-year efforts to develop the different underpinnings of 
financial markets and to strengthen the key public functions that can best promote and benefit 
from such finance deepening. These multi-year reform plans under ADB assistance inherently 
serve as an organizing framework for (i) continued coordination between development partners 
in Armenia working in public financial management (e.g. the International Monetary Fund [IMF] 
and  the  World  Bank)  and  capital  markets  development  (e.g.  the  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction and Development [EBRD]); and (ii) adequately identifying crucial sequencing 
challenges and other policy action implementation difficulties of this type of reform work.15 To 
ensure traction and continued policy dialogue, the second PPEF for 2020–2021 will also be 
supported by an ongoing ADB technical assistance (TA) project.16 
10.  Integration in government plans and development partner coordination. Reform 
areas addressed under the program are firmly anchored in the government’s 2019–2023 program 
and complementary to IMF support provided under the current Stand-By Arrangement.17 ADB 
continues to coordinate with the IMF and other donors to ensure that overall support to the 
government emphasizes a common set of priorities to help maintain macroeconomic stability and 
                                                
13 Footnote 1. Subprogram 1 ($40 million) was approved in 2017. Subprogram 2 ($50 million) was approved in 2018.   
14 ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Enhancing Governance and Capacity Development as Driver of Change. Manila. 
15 IMF. 2003. Managing Risks in Financial Market Development, The Role of Sequencing. Washington, DC. 
16 ADB. 2019. Preparing the Second Public Efficiency and Financial Markets Program. Manila. 
17 IMF. 2019. Stand-By Arrangement for Armenia. Yerevan.

4 
promote higher and inclusive economic growth. These priorities are broadly reflected in the 
government’s 2019–2023 program.18 In more specific relation to the scope of the proposed ADB 
program, the government program aims to (i) promote entrepreneurship, innovators, and their 
access to affordable and sustainable finance while ensuring efficient and sustainable fiscal 
policies and effective public debt management; and (ii) develop government debt markets to 
support high-value human and capital investments.19 The government program also explicitly 
refers to a fundamental development prerequisite: the need to develop capital markets and 
financial institutions as the way to sustainably expand affordable financial services in support of 
private sector competitiveness.20 This is presented as a pivotal common objective for both the 
government and the CBA to pursue. Under the IMF’s Stand-By Arrangement, the CBA will also 
aim  to  (i)  safeguard  financial  stability  by  improving  the  risk-based  supervision  framework, 
(ii) strengthen macroprudential measures in light of high levels of dollarization, (iii) enhance 
banks’ foreign currency liquidity buffers, and (iv) develop capital markets to mobilize long-term 
domestic capital to fund economic developments.  
11.  Reform area 1: Strengthening public debt and fiscal risk management policies and 
practices.  In  this  area,  the  program  continues  to  (i)  strengthen  the  effectiveness  of  the 
government’s  fiscal  risk  management  function,  (ii) promote  the  development  of  fiscally 
responsible and planning-relevant public–private partnerships (PPPs), and (iii) enhance market 
transparency and predictability in public debt management. To strengthen the government’s 
institutional capacity to ensure effective mapping and management of the risks that pose a threat 
to fiscal stability, and in the sequence of past efforts under ADB assistance (coordinated with IMF 
assistance), the government (i) approved the charter of  a new Fiscal Risks and Statistics 
Department21 (to elevate the institutional positioning of this role within MOF from a division to an 
actual department, and promote its access to information), and (ii) approved an update to the 
Roadmap of Fiscal Risks Management Improvement22 with the objective of establishing an 
integrated risk management framework (policy action 1; see policy matrix in Appendix 3).  
12.  MOF  will  be  considering  proposals  to  develop  the  required  human  resources  and 
analytical capacity of the new Fiscal Risks and Statistics Department during the second PPEF 
(2020–2021), so that it can fulfill its coordinating mandate with line ministries (as risk owners) and 
ensure that a new integrated fiscal risk management framework road map is implemented 
effectively. Under this second PPEF, the government will also aim to improve the transparency in 
the reporting and accounting of state-owned enterprises. This will all be complemented by the 
completion of a full-fledged risk vetting and monitoring framework for PPPs based on the new 
legal framework, with fiscal affordability limits and an explicit linkage to Armenia’s fiscal rule. 
                                                
18 The common emphasis is on four key pillars identified in the 2019–2023 government program: (i) anchoring fiscal 
policy on the fiscal rule to maintain debt sustainability; (ii) strengthening the monetary policy framework and 
maintaining a flexible exchange rate system; (iii) safeguarding the financial system and improving access to finance; 
and (iv) implementing structural reforms, with renewed emphasis on inclusiveness and governance. 
19 On fiscal management, see point 2 of section 1 and point 1 of section 3.2 of the government program (footnote 3). 
20 Section 5.3 of the new program recognizes the need for reforms to reduce the gaps, barriers, and issues in Armenia’s 
financial intermediation to mitigate risks, lower credit interest rates, and increase banking stability and credit 
opportunities  to  private  entrepreneurs.  Categorical  statements,  e.g.,  in  section  5.6,  that  developing  market 
mechanisms to bring investors in entrepreneurial assets in contact with domestic savers is “an important precondition 
for sustainable development,” are noteworthy and explicitly referred to as (i) a way of giving Armenian citizens access 
to diversified saving opportunities “through the acquisition of bonds or stocks of non-financial corporations”; (ii) a 
justification for “expanding the availability of alternative financial instruments (e.g., through the development of 
investment funds) and making easier for non-financial corporates to enter capital markets to issue securities (IPOs)”; 
and (iii) crucial to enable large-scale infrastructure investments and private sector participation in their development. 
21 To include vetting and mitigation responsibilities as well as monitoring and reporting of risks. 
22 Originally approved in 2017 through the Ministry of Finance order no. 448 dated 31 August 2017.

5 
13.  Under the program, ADB supported the legislative consultation processes led by the 
Ministry of Economy (MOE) and which resulted in Parliament approval of a PPP law in June 2019 
that is both fiscally responsible and planning-relevant (this was also coordinated with IMF 
assistance). This law includes key features such as: the exclusion of unsolicited proposals and 
institutional PPPs from its scope; clarity on the institutional distribution of roles for PPP pipeline 
development, as well as clarity on the fundamental principles and criteria for PPP development 
and approval; and awarding the MOF with a key gatekeeper role in PPP approvals. To promote 
stakeholder  awareness  of  the  underlying  policy  choices  taken  (and  for  overall  reform 
effectiveness), and based on the new law, the government also developed and circulated for inter-
ministerial consultations a draft government decree and the remaining methodologies/regulations 
and manuals of the needed operational framework for PPPs. To ensure the integration of PPPs 
with public investment management functions (also currently under development and supported 
by World Bank assistance), the MOE operationalized a PPP policy unit within the newly created 
Public Investment Policy Department (these efforts are included in policy action 2). 
14.  The institutionalization of an effective PPP legal and operational framework can guide the 
government to pursue PPP deals that are fiscally responsible and relevant to the country’s 
investment priorities. Ongoing ADB TA efforts focus on strengthening the government’s capacity 
to manage and assess risks in the current stock of concessions (currently around 10% of GDP). 
Through the second PPEF, the government (i) is committed to approving the PPP government 
decree and the remaining methodologies to complete the agreed-upon operational framework, 
and (ii) will approve amendments to the current procurement decree if these are confirmed to be 
required to accommodate the operational agenda under the new PPP law. Lastly, the government 
is also committed to continue investing in the institutional and human capacity of MOE for PPP 
identification, pipeline development, vetting and transaction structuring. 
15.  The program also aims to promote a more effective, credible, and better communicated 
public debt management strategy and implementation. The focus of current efforts is on helping 
to provide key annual strategic guidance and credible medium-term planning on the composition 
and overall management of public debt positions to markets and following through on that 
guidance with actual implementation. This is a crucial institutional behavior upgrade that needs 
to be sustainably achieved in Armenia. Under the proposed program, the MOF implemented 
Medium-Term Debt Strategy (MTDS), 2019–2021, within its benchmark targets for refinancing 
risk, interest rate risk, and exchange rate risk, with minimal deviations. MOF also approved an 
update of the MTDS for 2020–2022 with more stringent benchmarks in terms of reducing 
exposures to exchange rate risk and restructuring the composition of deficit financing toward 
increasing domestic borrowing.23 The MOF has also remained on track in the implementation of 
the Treasury Securities Issuance Plan, in terms of amounts and tenors, without any unjustified 
cancellations, and with producing regular due updates to market players. The MOF also approved 
and  publicized  guidelines  for  buying  government  securities  via  Treasury  Direct,  thereby 
expanding retail investors’ access to its Retail Debt Program (efforts included in policy action 3). 
16.  Under  the  second  PPEF  and  with  TA  support,  the  government  is  committed  to 
implementing the MTDS 2020–2022 with minimal deviations; and to updating and approving an 
MTDS 2021–2023 that continues targeting the strategic reduction of exposures to exchange rate 
risk and continue the shift towards increased reliance on domestic net borrowing.24  
                                                
23 The projected share for net borrowings in domestic securities in total new borrowings continues to increase at each 
new MTDS. Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Armenia. http://www.minfin.am/en/page/strategy/. 
24 The approach followed is that each annual MTDS update should be implemented within more stringent benchmark 
targets to reduce foreign currency exposure and increase the reliance on market-based instruments.

6 
17.  Reform  area  2:  Improving  government  securities  market  and  money  market 
infrastructure.  This  reform  area  is  centered  around  three  key  fronts:  (i)  strengthening 
collaboration  between  the  MOF  and  the  CBA  and  their  public  communication  regarding 
commitments to develop financial and capital markets; (ii) improving liquidity management and 
forecasting between CBA and MOF, while significantly improving the availability of benchmark 
securities and price-discovery in government securities; and (iii) implementing the Global Master 
Repurchase Agreement (GMRA) to establish liquid secured interbank markets. EBRD assistance 
is also supportive of this reform agenda. Collaboration between the CBA and MOF in developing 
financial and capital markets must be promoted, as well as the communication and collaboration 
with  financial  market  players  in  the  setting  of  priorities.  The  program  promotes  this  close 
collaboration between the MOF and CBA, through the joint public reporting on progress made 
along the time-bound road map for the medium-term development of capital and financial markets 
in the country (this is policy action 4).25 Under the second PPEF, the MOF and CBA are expected 
to approve a full-fledged financial and capital market development program to be approved by the 
cabinet of ministers, and ADB assistance will continue to emphasize the importance of and 
support its market consultations, for its relevance and ultimate effectiveness.  
18.  Under the program, the Public Debt Management Department (PDMD) operationalized 
the cash management framework and implemented a road map to upgrade its cash management 
and improve its interface with the systemic liquidity management and forecasting of the CBA. In 
addition, the MOF (i.e. PDMD) implemented key modifications to further develop the Regular 
Treasury Bill Program and the primary dealership, market-making system (these efforts are 
included in policy action 5). Under the second PPEF, the PDMD is committed to finalizing the 
implementation of the road map to improve cash management, and the CBA is committed to 
approving all the regulations for the Stock Exchange to offer bond switch auction solutions. 
19.  To establish the conditions for liquid secured interbank markets, the CBA continued to 
implement key steps of the time-bound GMRA road map. Among others, these include submitting 
legal amendments to cabinet to ultimately eliminate re-characterization risks in repo (interbank) 
transactions (included in policy action 6).26 These legal amendments require parliamentary 
approval, which will be supported under the second PPEF as well as the remaining steps of the 
time-bound GMRA road map. This will entail (i) final parliamentary approval of legal reforms to 
address re-characterization risks, (ii) CBA issuance of an Armenia GMRA annex, (iii) issuance of 
the GMRA legal opinion, and (iv) approval of the memorandum of understanding (or general 
agreement)  between  the  CBA  and  commercial  banks  to  facilitate  the  systems’  wholesale 
transition to the GMRA. Through the second PPEF, the CBA is committed to approve interest rate 
benchmarking proposals and introduce enhancements in the real-time gross settlement system. 
20.  Reform area 3: Broadening the base of instruments and investors and enhancing 
corporate transparency. In this area, this reform agenda aims to sustain previous efforts to 
strengthen the legal and regulatory framework for new instruments and corporate transparency—
to encourage both more active investors and issuers  into participating in Armenian capital 
markets.27 The  reform  efforts  pursue  three  key  policy  objectives:  (i)  developing  the  legal 
framework for new types of securities and to broaden the investor base, (ii) developing the legal

21.  Under the program, the government promoted a number of important reforms to help 
develop new types of securities and broaden the investor base. Notably, the CBA approved the 
set of subsidiary regulations to implement a new law for residential mortgage lending, took 
initiatives to set clear rules for investment companies to remove the inconsistency between 
regulatory regimes of investment companies and other foreign exchange market participants 
linked to the foreign currency buy/sell services, and revised relevant regulations of investment 
companies and funds (including pension funds) taking into account the amendments to the 
International Financial Reporting Standard 16.28 The CBA also took to regulate non-standardized 
derivative financial instruments to reduce risks and issued norms to improve the availability of all 
central depository services for investment and fund managers without mediation (policy action 7). 
22.  Under the second PPEF, the CBA is committed to examining regulatory and tax incentive 
options  to  encourage  corporate  debt  issuance.  This  will  include  a  full  examination  of  tax 
impediments to securities issuance to be shared with stakeholders for public consultation. In 
addition,  the  government  and  CBA  are  expected  to  jointly  issue  draft  policy  guidance 
recommendations to ensure that, in the case of international financial institutions financing large 
infrastructure companies, (i) preconditions are set in the project design to promote different 
financial instruments in local currency; and (ii) wholesale financing initiatives promote financial 
transparency and stress the need for credit ratings and external audits. 
23.  Developing a legal framework for private equity is expected to result in an increase over 
time of the volume of resources mobilized through deepening financial markets. Under the 
program, Parliament approved amendments proposed by the government to introduce modern 
elements of corporate law. These include (i) the concept of a shareholder’s agreement and 
(ii) protection of minority investors’ rights. The government has also approved and submitted legal 
amendments to Parliament that allows single proprietorships to buy shares of limited liability 
companies (included in policy action 8). The development of an effective insolvency framework is 
a crucial pillar of capital market development. To establish effective insolvency practices, the 
government established and operationalized specialized courts for insolvency proceedings with 
dedicated  full-time  judges.  It  also  submitted  amendments  to  the  insolvency  framework  to 
Parliament  with  the  objective  of  improving  bankruptcy  processes  and  the  effectiveness  of 
specialized courts for insolvency proceedings (included in policy action 9).  
24.  Under the second PPEF, the government is committed to taking steps to maximize the 
performance of the specialized courts for insolvency and consider improvements to the insolvency 
legislation to ensure that insolvency proceedings are geared towards maximizing the return to 
creditors. Also under the second PPEF, following parliamentary approval (which is expected in 
November 2019) of (i) amendment proposals to the laws on accounting and auditing; (ii) a new 
proposed law on regulation and public oversight of audit and accounting (to delegate regulatory 
functions to a new public oversight board and the prospective chamber of accountants and 
auditors of Armenia); and (iii) legislative proposals to establish mandatory audits, the MOF is 
committed to approving all the necessary sub-legislation and facilitating the establishment of the 
new self-regulating architecture for the accounting and auditing professions and practices.

C.  Impacts of the Reform 
25.  The ultimate impact of this reform agenda will be fiscal sustainability and resilience in the 
finance sector of Armenia increased by 2022. The program aims to deepen the financial market 
in Armenia while strengthening the public administration’s ability to manage public debt and fiscal 
risks via a combination of policy actions (all completed before Board circulation in October 2019). 
This will be followed up with the second PPEF.  
 
26.  In terms of medium-term results expected and expressed qualitatively:  
•  Reform area 1 aims to (i) achieve significant upgrades in fiscal credibility and establish an 
issuance program that is conducive to market development and dominates debt policy 
and borrowing practices; (ii) complete an effective framework that only promotes fiscally 
responsible  and  planning-relevant  PPPs;  and  (iii)  establish  an  effective  capacity  to 
manage and assess the risks in the current stock of and forthcoming PPPs. Risk premiums 
and rating outlooks would be expected to gradually reflect these efforts and developments, 
which naturally can get transmitted across the economy as lower financial costs;29  
•  Reform area 2 aims to help establish a liquid yield curve along key tenors, promoting liquid 
money markets (in terms of trading turnover) and establishing formal pricing benchmarks 
in local currency for the entire economy. This also requires bolder market-based public 
debt issuance efforts that, in local currency, are tantamount to taking on more refinancing 
risk in exchange for a prospective reduction in liquidity premiums, and that in foreign 
currency preserve benchmarks. This would be expected to significantly and sustainably 
improve  access  to finance  in  local  currency  to  private  businesses  in  the  Armenian 
economy;30  
•  In reform area 3, and at the end of the proposed program and of the second PPEF, the 
expectation is that capital markets can become more active and viable to the private sector 
in Armenia, as pricing benchmarks in local currency would have been established and 
regulatory and tax barriers removed. 
D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
27.  The government has requested a regular loan of €36,506,000 ($40,000,000-equivalent)31 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the program. The loan will have a 15-year 
term, including a grace period of 3 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 
0.15% per year and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based 
on the straight-line method, the average loan maturity is 9.25 years and there is no maturity 
premium payable to ADB. The loan amount is 22% of the projected financing gap in 2019, 
reflecting planned development expenditures and relevant essential recurrent expenditures.32

28.  Subject to government request, ADB will stand ready to explore further policy-based 
lending on the basis of the reform engagement with the different implementing agencies during 
the second PPEF. The current medium-term fiscal projections produce significant uncertainty with 
regard to development financing needs in 2020–2021, which reflects a combination of factors and 
expectations. For example: (i) the current fiscal overperformance in tax revenue is assumed to 
continue in 2020, and (ii) the recent success with sizable market-based debt issuances is factored 
into the possibilities for 2020 in terms of the ability to fill financing gaps with a much higher reliance 
on market-based domestic borrowing and subsequent tapping of the foreign exchange market. 
Also, the government is facing difficulties in capital expenditure execution in 2019 that might 
produce non-negligible expenditure carryovers to 2020, which can add to the uncertainty in the 
government’s general financing requirements during 2019–2021.33 These expectations may be 
considered optimistic, but they reveal a new level of revenue mobilization and public debt 
management  confidence  that  must  be  supported.  One  of  the  objectives  of  ADB’s  current 
assistance to Armenia is to support MOF in moving towards a much higher reliance on market-
based domestic borrowing. Successful implementation of these fiscal strategies in 2020–2021 will 
depend not only on the effective implementation of key reforms under the program but also on 
continuous fiscal revenue performance.34  
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
29.   The MOF is the executing agency. The CBA, the Ministry of Economy, and the MOF are 
implementing  agencies  in  their  respective  reform  outputs.35 The  implementation  period  is 
November 2018–October 2019 for the reforms included as conditionality. All policy actions have 
already  been  accomplished.  The  proceeds  of  the  policy-based  loan  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended from time to time).
